awd_titl_txt: Probing Low Frequency Vibrational Modes in Molecular Crystals and Developing Terahertz Spectroscopic Polarimetry
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Charles Schmuttenmaer of Yale University and his postdoctoral, graduate and undergraduate student colleagues are studying a technique called terahertz vibrational circular dichroism. Vibrational circular dichroism (VCD) in the mid-infra-red region is a very useful technique that provides three-dimensional structural information about molecules. It has applications for both small and complex systems. Species such as muscle proteins, DNA, amino acids, and proteins have been studied. This project is extending VCD in the terahertz region of the spectrum (the middle ground between microwave and infra-red radiation). This is a new frontier that allows the exploration of motions that occur over an entire molecule. Applications are envisaged from amino acid crystals and carbohydrates, to pharmaceuticals, to explosives, and others. There is a strong outreach component to socioeconomically disadvantaged middle- and high-school students. In addition, undergraduate research opportunities at Yale will be strengthened.

There has been a great deal of recent work using THz time-domain spectroscopy to characterize the low frequency vibrational modes in organic molecular crystals (OMCs). While THz spectra of many OMCs have been reported, assigning them has been exceedingly difficult. This project is using new approaches to understand the complex motions underlying these low frequency modes. Insight is gained through isotopic substitution as well as dependence on external parameters such as pressure and temperature. The spectra of several chemically related OMCs are calculated and measured in order to identify and describe which motions are common to them, and which are unique. The THz VCD spectra are measured and provide experimental data that constrain possible peak assignments. One objective is to measure the THz VCD spectrum of an OMC for the first time.

por.por_cntn:
Organic molecular compounds, such as amino acids and peptides, are at the center of many chemical processes and life in general. This makes a rigorous understanding of these materials particularly important to explain organo/bio-chemical processes. A large variety of techniques are used to explore the composition and behavior of these materials. For example, NMR and mass spectrometry. Additionally, the crystal structure of organic molecular crystals (OMCs) can be investigated using X-ray techniques. However, as is well known, all experimental techniques have advantages and short-falls.

Our work focused on establishing Terahertz (THz) spectroscopy as a technique to probe structural-functional relations in OMCs. THz spectroscopy utilizes the spectral range between 100 µm and 1000 µm, which corresponds to frequencies of 0.3 THz to 3 THz, energies of 1.2 to 12 meV, and wavenumbers of 10-100 cm-1 (depending on your choice of units).

The THz spectral range is lower in energy than infra-red and visible light. This provides several intriguing advantages, as the experimental probe beam does not heat or damage the sample. The photon temperature at THz frequencies corresponds to 50 K, which means that at room temperature the modes probed are populated above the ground state. Therefore, the corresponding movement and vibrations are present in a room temperature OMC.  These modes are important for chemical reactions and conformational changes in organic materials.

The main goal of this project was to increase the accuracy of density functional theory (DFT) calculations of OMCs as well as the experimental accuracy. Thanks to the improvement in our spectrometer, we were able to characterize several amino acids for the first time in the THz range. We focused our experiments on DL-Norleucine (DL-Nle), DL-Norvaline (DL-Nva), and DL-Methionine (DL-Met).

DL-Nva was studied because it undergoes a solid-solid phase transition at about 180 K. Most phase-transitions occur via a nucleation and growth processes in which the new phase grows from a single seed into the surrounding high-temperature phase. This process does not follow a strict order. In contrast Martensitic transitions, as the one suspected in DL-Nva, are constrained. The transitions occurs by a sliding movement of a unit layer with respect to the neighboring layer. This sliding movement is reversible, and after a forward and a backward transition a molecule will still have the same molecules as neighbors. This unique property is particularly important for mechanical-memory effect materials. Furthermore, the sliding movement results in a macroscopic deformation which has potential applications in molecular machines. For our experiments, DL-Nva was measured as a pure material and with well-defined dopants. These dopants are incorporated into the unit cell of the OMC and suppressed the phase transition. Our results strongly indicate that the occurring transition is Martensitic in character.

The second set of amino acids studied was DL-Nle and DL-Met. These amino acids differ in only one position, in which the CH2 group in DL-Nle is replaced with a sulfur. This substitution does not significantly change the lattice geometry. These materials were chosen as a model system to demonstrate that THz spectroscopy is sensitive to the chemical compounds.

Additionally, quantum-mechanical calculations were performed to determine the spectrum of the material. These spectral information conformed our experimental results. Even more importantly, the computations provided us with an in-depth understanding of the molecular movements at the resonance frequencies. This information is used to visualize the displacement of individual atoms at the resonance. We could confirm, that the modes which are nearly-identical in DL-Met and DL-Nle are localized further away from the sulfur atom, where the modes which shift in frequency involve the sulfur. The mode analysis provided an excellent explanation for the observed similarities and difference in the two spectra. 

Based on the amino acid results we also applied our spectroscopic technique on a peptide consisting of four different amino acids. Our experiments are the first THz-spectra collected for oligo-peptides. The experimental results are confirmed with calculations. We were able to identify different peptides which exhibit identical (+/- 1%) crystal structure and distinguish peptides that only differ in the chirality of one of the four amino acids (D-Proline vs L-Proline).

The final sample system studied with our spectrometer consists of biological nanowires. These wires are grown by geobacter sulfureduces and exhibit electrical conductivity as measured by DC electrical conductivity measurements. However, our results demonstrate that they also exhibit conductivity at high frequencies within the THz range.
